herstories.December 10, 1869: Wyoming is the first territory to give women the right to vote
herstories.November 14, 1903 \u2013: e U.S. Women’s Trade Union League is established
herstories.October 11, 1984: Dr. Kathryn D. Sullivan is the first U.S. woman astronaut to “walk” in space during Challenger flight
herstories.December 1, 1955\u00a0: osa Parks refuses to give up her seat on a bus to a white person; her arrest sparks the modern civil rights movement in the US
herstories.October 15, 1948: Dr. Frances L. Willoughby is the first woman doctor in the regular U.S. Navy
herstories.September 26, 1973\u00a0: Capt. Lorraine Potter, an American Baptist minister, becomes the first woman U.S. Air Force chaplain
herstories.December 5, 1935: Mary McLeod Bethune creates the National Council of Negro Women
herstories.July 20, 1942: The first class of Women’s Auxiliary Army Corps (WAAC) begins at Fort Des Moines, IA
herstories.October 16, 1916: Margaret Sanger opens the U.S.’s first birth control clinic in Brooklyn, New York
herstories.September 25, 1981: Sandra Day O’Connor is sworn in as the first woman U.S. Supreme Court Justice
herstories.July 19-20, 1848: The Seneca Falls Convention, the country’s first women’s rights convention, is held in Seneca Falls, New York Women’s Rights Movement
herstories.November 14, 1889: Journalist Elizabeth Cochran, aka Nellie Bly, sails around the world in 72 days, 6 hours, 11 minutes, and 14 seconds, beating the fictional record set by Phineas Fogg in Jules Verne’s Around the World in Eighty Days
herstories.January 8, 1977\u00a0: auli Murray is ordained as the first female African American Episcopal priest
herstories.August 8, 1969\u00a0\u2013\u00a0: cutive order 11478 issued by President Nixon requires each federal department and agency to establish and maintain an affirmative action program of equal employment opportunity for civilian employees and applicants
herstories.November 28, 1881: The first organizational meeting is held for the predecessor group to the American Association of University Women (AAUW)
herstories.September 29, 1988\u00a0: Stacy Allison becomes first American woman to reach the summit of Mt. Everest
herstories.July 4, 1876: Suffragists crash the Centennial Celebration in Independence Hall to present the Vice President with the “Declaration of the Rights of Women” written by Matilda Joselyn Gage
herstories.January 11, 1935: Amelia Earhart makes the first solo flight from Hawaii to North America
herstories.December 13, 1993\u00a0: usan A. Maxman becomes first woman president of the American Institute of Architects in its 135 year history
herstories.May 29, 1943: “Rosie the Riveter” by Norman Rockwell appears on the cover of the Saturday Evening Post
herstories.January 7, 1896: Fanny Farmer’s first cookbook is published in which she standardized cooking measurements
herstories.May 8, 1914: President Woodrow Wilson signs a Proclamation designating the second Sunday in May as Mother’s Day
herstories.April 7, 1987: Opening of the National Museum of Women in the Arts in Washington, D.C., the first museum devoted to women artists
herstories.October 8, 1993 \u2013: ni Morrison becomes the first African American woman to win the Nobel Prize for Literature
herstories.January 7, 1955: Marian Anderson is the first African American woman to sing at the Metropolitan Opera
herstories.December 14, 1961: President’s Commission on the Status of Women is established to examine discrimination against women and ways to eliminate it
herstories.July 12, 1984: Representative Geraldine Ferraro (D-New York) is chosen as the first female to run for Vice President of the United States on the Democratic Party ticket with Walter Mondale (D-Minnesota)
herstories.October 10, 1983: Dr. Barbara McClintock receives the Nobel Prize for Medicine for her discovery in genetics about mobile genetic elements
herstories.July 2, 1937: Amelia Earhart’s plane is lost in the Pacific Ocean near Howland Island
herstories.November 14, 1946: Emily Greene Balch, co-founder of the Women’s International League for Peace and Freedom, is awarded the Nobel Peace Prize
herstories.August 10, 1993\u00a0\u2013\u00a0: h Bader Ginsburg is sworn in as the second woman and 107th Justice to serve on the US Supreme Court
herstories.April 19, 1977: Fifteen women in the House of Representatives form the Congressional Caucus for Women’s Issues
herstories.August 9, 1995\u00a0\u2013\u00a0: erta Cooper Ramo becomes the first woman to hold the office of president of the American Bar Association
herstories.September 14, 1964\u00a0: Helen Keller receives the Presidential Medal of Freedom along with 4 other women: Dr. Lena Edwards, Lynn Fontainne, Dr. Helen Taussig, and Leontyne Price
herstories.November 8, 1984: Dr. Anna L. Fisher, a physician on the shuttle Discovery, becomes the first American mother and third American woman to fly into space
herstories.April 26, 1777: American Revolution heroine Sybil Ludington, 16 years old, rides 40 miles on horseback in the middle of the night to warn the American militia that the British were invading
herstories.September 12, 1910\u00a0: Alice Stebbins Wells, a former social worker, becomes the first woman police officer with arrest powers in the U.S. (Los Angeles, CA)
herstories.September 14, 1975: Elizabeth Ann Seton is canonized and becomes the first American-born saint, founded the first U.S. Order of the Sisters of Charity of St. Joseph
herstories.April 5, 1911: 100,000 to 500,000 people march in New York City to attend the funeral of seven unidentified victims of the Triangle Shirtwaist Company fire in late March
herstories.January 3, 1949: Margaret Chase Smith (R-Maine) starts her tenure in the Senate, where she stays in office until 1973, became the first woman to serve in both the House and Senate as she previously served in the House (1940-49)
herstories.May 12, 1968\u00a0: 12-block Mother’s Day march of “welfare mothers” is held in Washington, D.C., led by Coretta Scott King accompanied by Ethel Kennedy
herstories.June 10, 1963\u00a0\u2013: al Pay Act enacted: “To prohibit discrimination on account of sex in the payment of wages by employers engaged in commerce or in the production of goods for commerce.” (PL 88-38)
herstories.November 11, 1979 \u2013: thune Museum and Archives opens in Washington D.C. as a center for African-American women’s history, honoring Mary McLeod Bethune
herstories.July 7, 1981: President Reagan nominates Sandra Day O’Connor as the first woman Supreme Court Justice?
herstories.September 26, 1971: Rep. Shirley Chisholm (D-New York) announces she will enter the Democratic presidential primaries
herstories.November 11, 1993: The Vietnam Women’s Memorial is dedicated in Washington, D.C. after being conceived by former army combat nurse Diane Carlson Evans and sculpted by Glenna Goodacre to honor the 265,000 women who voluntarily served during the Vietnam era
herstories.May 10, 1872: Victoria Woodhull is nominated as the first woman candidate for U.S. president for the Equal Rights Party
herstories.November 1, 1848 \u2013: rst medical school for women, the New England Female Medical School, opens, in 1874 it merges with Boston University to become one of the world’s first co-ed medical schools
herstories.May 29, 1977\u00a0: anet Guthrie becomes the first woman to qualify for and complete the Indy 500 car race
herstories.June 9, 1949\u00a0\u2013: rgia Neese Clark confirmed as the first woman treasurer of the United States
herstories.December 17, 1993\u00a0: udith Rodin is named president of Univ. of Pennsylvania, the first woman to head an Ivy League institution
herstories.October 28, 1958: Mary Roebling is the first woman director of a stock exchange (American Stock Exchange)
herstories.July 6, 1957: Althea Gibson is the first African American woman player to win a Wimbledon title in women’s tennis singles
herstories.October 23, 1910: Blanche Stuart Scott is the first American woman pilot to make a public flight
herstories.October 24, 1956 \u2013: verend Margaret Towner is the first woman ordained a minister in the Presbyterian Church
herstories.December 14, 1985: Wilma Mankiller is sworn in as principal chief of the Cherokee Nation of Oklahoma – the first woman in modern history to lead a major Native American tribe
herstories.August 26, 1970\u00a0\u2013\u00a0: ty Friedan leads a nationwide protest called the “Women’s Strike for Equality” in New York City on the fiftieth anniversary of women’s suffrage
herstories.July 2, 1964: President Lyndon Johnson signs the Civil Rights Act; Title VII prohibits sex discrimination in employment
herstories.August 12, 1972\u00a0\u2013\u00a0: dy Rue founds the National Association for Female Executives (NAFE), the largest businesswomen’s organization in the United States
herstories.September 20, 1973: Billie Jean King defeats Bobby “No-Broad-Can-Beat-Me” Riggs in the battle of the sexes tennis match
herstories.October 4, 1993: Ruth Bader Ginsburg joins the U.S. Supreme Court as its second woman Justice
herstories.August 30, 1984\u00a0\u2013\u00a0: ith A. Resnick is the second U.S. woman in space, traveling on the first flight of the space shuttle Discovery
herstories.August 26, 1971\u00a0\u2013\u00a0: first Women’s Equality Day, initiated by Representative Bella Abzug, is established by Presidential Proclamation and reaffirmed annually
herstories.November 8, 1910 \u2013: e state of Washington passes a constitutional amendment to guarantee woman suffrage
herstories.June 1, 1993\u00a0\u2013: nie Chung becomes the second woman to co-anchor the evening news, 17 years after Barbara Walters became the first in 1976
herstories.January 29, 1926: Violette Neatly Anderson is the first black woman to practice law before the U.S. Supreme Court
herstories.July 2, 1979: The Susan B. Anthony dollar is released
herstories.June 20, 1921\u00a0\u2013: ce Robertson (R-Oklahoma) becomes the first woman to chair the House of Representatives
herstories.November 13, 1938 \u2013: ther Francis Xavier Cabrini is beatified, the first American woman citizen to become a saint
herstories.August 28, 1963\u00a0\u2013\u00a0: e than 250,000 gather for a march on Washington, DC, and listen to Martin Luther King, Jr.’s famous “I Have a Dream” speech
herstories.July 14, 1917: 16 women from the National Women’s Party were arrested while picketing the White House demanding universal women’s suffrage; they were charged with obstructing traffic
herstories.June 17, 1873\u00a0\u2013: an B. Anthony’s trial starts for illegally voting in Rochester, New York, on November 5, 1872
herstories.October 4, 1976 \u2013: rbara Walters becomes the first woman co-anchor of the evening news (at ABC)
herstories.August 14, 1986\u00a0\u2013\u00a0: r Admiral Grace Murray Hopper retires from active duty in the US Navy. A pioneering computer scientist and inventor of the computer language COBOL, she was the oldest officer still on active duty at the time of her retirement
herstories.December 7, 1941: Capt. Annie Fox receives the first Purple Heart awarded to a woman for her service while under attack at Pearl Harbor
herstories.April 13, 1933: Ruth Bryan Owen is the first woman to represent the U.S. as a foreign minister when she is appointed as envoy to Denmark
herstories.December 28, 1967: Muriel Siebert becomes the first woman to own a seat on the N.Y. Stock Exchange
herstories.April 9, 1939: Marian Anderson sings an Easter Sunday concert for more than 75,000 at Lincoln Memorial
herstories.August 23, 1902\u00a0\u2013\u00a0: ny Farmer opens the “School of Cookery” in Boston, MA
herstories.May 21, 1932\u00a0: melia Earhart Putnam becomes the first woman to complete a solo-transatlantic flight by flying 2,026 miles from Newfoundland toIreland in just under 15 hours
herstories.June 21, 1997\u00a0\u2013: Women’s National Basketball Association (WNBA) plays its first game
herstories.April 22: Earth Day, honor Rachel Carson today, a woman who changed America and greatly influenced the environmental movement with her revolutionary book, Silent Spring.
herstories.May 1, 1950\u00a0: wendolyn Brooks becomes the first African-American woman to receive the Pulitzer Prize for Poetry, named Library of Congress’s Consultant in Poetry (later called Poet Laureate) in 1985
herstories.July 29, 1974.\u00a0\u201c: ladelphia Eleven” deacons (Merrill Bittner, Alla Bozarth-Campbell, Alison Cheek, Emily Hewitt, Carter Heyward, Suzanne Hiatt, Marie Moorefield, Jeannette Piccard, Betty Schiess, Katrina Swanson, and Nancy Wittig) ordained as the first women Episcopal priests
herstories.June 23, 1972\u00a0\u2013: le IX of the Education Amendments of 1972 is signed by President Nixon, one of the most important legislation initiatives passed for women and girls since women won the vote in 1920. This legislation guarantees equal access and equal opportunity for female and male students in almost all aspects of our educational systems
herstories.January 12, 1932: Hattie Wyatt Caraway (D-Arkansas) is the first woman elected to the U.S. Senate, becomes the first woman to chair a Senate Committee and the first to serve as the Senate’s presiding officer
herstories.April 28, 1993: First “Take Our Daughters to Work” Day, sponsored by the Ms. Foundation, in 2003 it became “Take Our Daughters and Sons to Work” Day
herstories.May 5, 1938: Dr. Dorothy H. Andersen presents results of her medical research identifying the disease cystic fibrosis at a meeting of the American Pediatric Association
herstories.April 2, 1931: 17-year-old Jackie Mitchell, the second woman to play baseball in the all-male minor leagues, pitches an exhibition game against the N.Y. Yankees and strikes out both Babe Ruth and Lou Gehrig. The next day, the Baseball Commissioner voided her contract, claiming baseball was too strenuous for women. The ban was not overturned until 1992
herstories.May 21, 1973: Lynn Genesko, a swimmer, receives the first athletic scholarship awarded to a woman (University of Miami)
herstories.December 10, 1938\u00a0: earl S. Buck receives the Nobel Prize for Literature for The Good Earth
herstories.August 6, 1965 \u2013: e Voting Rights Act outlaws the discriminatory literacy tests that had been used to prevent African Americans from voting. Suffrage is finally fully extended to African American women
herstories.October 3, 1904: Mary McLeod Bethune opens her first school for African-American students in Daytona Beach, Florida
herstories.January 25, 1980: Mary Decker became the first woman to run a mile under 4 1/2 minutes, running it at 4:17.55
herstories.April 7, 1805: acagawea begins helping the Lewis and Clark Expedition as an interpreter
herstories.June 25, 1903\u00a0\u2013: ie Curie defends her doctoral thesis on radioactive substances at Université de la Sorbonne in Paris, becoming the first woman in France to receive a doctoral degree
herstories.June 11, 1913\u00a0\u2013: en in Illinois celebrate passage of a state woman suffrage bill allowing women to vote in presidential elections
herstories.January 5, 1925: Nellie Tayloe Ross is inaugurated as the first woman Governor in U.S. history (Governor of Wyoming)
